statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \tan^3 2 x \sec 2 x

step.context: \text{Are the following calculations and analysis correct?}
step.tex:
\begin{align} \tan^3 2 x \sec 2 x &= \tan^2 2x \cdot \tan 2x \sec 2x \\ &= (\sec^2 2x -1) \tan 2x \sec 2x \\ &= \sec^2 2x \cdot \tan 2x \sec 2x - \tan 2x \sec 2x \end{align} \\
\implies \int \tan^3 2 x \sec 2 x \, dx \\ = \int \sec^2 2x \cdot \tan 2x \sec 2x \, dx - \int \tan 2x \sec 2x \, dx \\ = \int \sec^2 2x \cdot \tan 2x \sec 2x \, dx - \dfrac{\sec 2x}{2} +C_1
step.reason: \text{Applied the trigonometric identity, }\\ 1 + \tan^2 x = \sec^2 x \text{ and}\\\text{substituted } \int \tan 2x \sec 2x \, dx = \dfrac{\sec 2x}{2} \\ \text{Check your calculations, if you got something}\\ \text{else.}

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ \int \sec^2 2x \cdot \tan 2x \sec 2x \, dx - \dfrac{\sec 2x}{2} +C_1 \quad \text{correct}?
step.reason: \int x^n dx = \dfrac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C \\ \text{ where C is the constant of integration.}
